Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: The spontaneous down-conversion of laser light in a dielectric plate and/or metal-dielectric interface is considered. It is found that strong enhancement of the process takes place near the critical intensity of excitation. The enhancement of the efficiency takes place if the amplitude of oscillations of the eikonal coincides with the wavelength of emission. The down-conversion in metal-coated SNOM tip may be used for the generation of completely polarization- entangled photon pairs.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Spontaneous nonparametric down-conversion of photons—the creation of photon pairs to the expense of the single photons of laser in the case of absence of the feedback is the nonlinear quantum phenomenon which takes place due to the existence of the zero-point fluctuations of the field. In this process the laser light, due to second-order nonlinear interaction perturbs periodically in time the refractive index which causes the periodical perturbation of the zero-point state and the emission of the photon pairs [1–11]. The process belongs to the phenomena of general importance while it is a consequence of the fundamental fact established by the quantum theory that the vacuum of space is not empty: it is full of quantum fluctuations. The latter fluctuations show up e.g. as emitted photons if the zero-point state undergoes time-dependent perturbations. It is of remarkable interest also from practical point of view while generated photon pairs are in the entangled state. At the usual conditions the process has extremely low probability and is observed only in case of positive feedback, e.g. in parametric oscillators. However, at present there exist possibilities not only to use strong laser light but also to enhance the interaction of light with matter using e.g. surface plasmon-polaritons, and in this way to increase the intensity of the down-conversion.

The time-dependence of the zero-point state of the field can also be achieved if the boundary conditions in time are changed, e.g. by taking a resonator and modulating in time its length. The two-photon emission, which arises in this case, is called the dynamic Casimir effect [10–15], referring to the fact that the usual (static) Casimir effect [12]—the attraction of the mutually parallel light reflecting plates, displays the existence of the zero-point energy of the electromagnetic field. The emission, which is generated in a resonator with periodically changing boundary conditions has been studied by several authors (see, e.g., [12–21]). In this case, the frequency of the one or several modes of the resonator is periodically changed. If the half of the period of modulation of frequency coincides with the period of the mode then the parametric resonance takes place resulting in the excitation of the mode. In this case the energy of the mode is exponentially growing in time.

However, this mechanism of the enhancement of radiation takes place only in case of a resonator (cavity) having discrete modes with rather different frequencies: only in this case the periodical change of the frequency of a mode will not mix it with other modes of the cavity which would destroy the parametric resonance. This mechanism can be used for the microwaves, when the characteristic size of the resonator is of the order of cm. In case of visible light this mechanism cannot be used due to very small size of the resonator which in this case should be comparable to the wavelength of light. The dynamical Casimir effect for microwaves was recently observed in [22, 23].

In this communication we consider the two-photon emission in visible frequency excited by the standing laser wave in a dielectric plate or an excited by the laser beam in metal/dielectric interface. In the latter case the plasmon-polaritons can be generated. Here the field enhancement takes place allowing one to increase the intensity of the down-conversion. Two possible geometries of the set-up are considered: the wave front of the standing wave of the laser is (1) parallel or (2) perpendicular to the interface. In the first case the dielectric is supposed to have the non-zero second-order nonlinear susceptibility χ (2). In the second case this non-zero value of χ (2) of the dielectric is not needed while for the waves propagating along the interface the required components of χ (2) differ from zero due to the inherent asymmetrical structure of the interface.

The arising emission results from the field-induced fast modulation of the optical length (eikonal) in time, which, in its turn, leads to a fast modulation of the zero-point state of the quantum field. In the case under consideration the emitting system is open, i.e. the feedback coupling is absent. The process under consideration is (quasi)stationary. The emission has a noticeable intensity only if the velocity V of the oscillations of the optical length is approaching the velocity of light c 0. Although usually the latter condition is very difficult to fulfill, modern light sources may have sufficient power to modulate the dielectric so strongly that the case with V=c 0 or even with V>c 0 can be achieved. Obviously it is of interest to know how the light conversion depends on the laser power in this case. Below we propose an answer to this question.

Section1.Heading: Emission of dielectric with oscillating in time optical length
Section1.Para:
Let us first consider the quantum emission of a dielectric with a periodically time-dependent refractive index n(t). The time-dependence of n may be achieved, e.g. if the dielectric is exposed in a strong standing laser wave. We restrict ourselves to the consideration of the emission in a fixed direction. Then the equation for the field operator of a mode with the frequency ω has the form [9–11] 1
$$ \bigl[ \partial^{2} / \partial t^{2} - \bigl(c_{0}/n(t) \bigr)^{2}\partial^{2} / \partial x^{2} \bigr] \hat{A} = 0, $$ where n(t)≈n+n′cosω 0 t,
$$n' = \chi^{(2)}(\omega_{0};\omega, \omega_{0} - \omega )E_{0}(\omega_{0}), $$
E 0(ω 0) is the amplitude of the standing laser wave of the frequency ω 0, c 0 is the velocity of light in vacuum (the polarization indices of the third-order tensor χ (2) are omitted; the components of this tensor satisfy the Kleinman symmetry conditions of the lossless dielectric).

For the convenience of consideration, we suppose that the dielectric is placed into a resonator, the length of which L 0 tends to infinity. We also suppose that only a part of the dielectric is excited; at that the refractive index slowly changes with the coordinate x. This allows one to use Eq. (1) with n(t) replaced by n(t,x).The field operator satisfies the boundary conditions, which means that it turns to zero at the borders at any time moment. Taking for the coordinates of the mirrors x 0=0 and x 1=L 0, both Eq. (1) and the boundary conditions are satisfied if
$\hat{A}(x,t)$ is chosen in the form 2
$$ \hat{A}(x,t) = \sum_{k} \sin \bigl(\pi kl(t,x)/l(t) \bigr)\hat{A}_{k}(t), $$ where k=0,±1,±2,… ,
$l(t,x) = \int_{0}^{x} dx'n(t,x')$ is the optical length (eikonal) at the coordinate x and the time moment t,l(t) is the full optical length.

Section1.Heading: Arbitrary intensity of excitation
Section1.Para:
To find the emission for an arbitrary velocity, we follow the calculations given in [9–11] (see part 2, the k=2 case). We use the equation of motion for the operator
$\hat{Q}$ : 17
$$ \hat{Q}(t) = \hat{Q}^{(0)}(t) + 2v\omega_{0} \int _{0}^{t} dt_{1}G(t - t_{1}) \cos (\omega_{0}t_{1})\hat{Q}(t_{1}) $$ (t≤t 0), which directly follows from Eqs. (6)–(7). Here
$\hat{Q}^{(0)}$ is given by Eq. (8) for
$\hat{Q}$ with
$\hat{A}_{j}^{(0)} $ instead of
$\hat{A}_{j}$ ,
$$G(t) = \bigl(\varTheta (t)/\pi \kappa_{0}^{2} \bigr)\sum _{k = 1}^{\kappa_{0}} k\sin\omega_{k}t $$ is the Green function. Using Eq. (17) once again (this time for
$\hat{Q}(t_{1})$ ) and inserting it into D(t,t′) we find
$$\begin{aligned} D \bigl(t,t' \bigr) \simeq& d \bigl(t,t' \bigr) \\ &{}+ 2v \omega_{0}\int_{0}^{t} dt_{1}\,G(t - t_{1})\cos (\omega_{0}t_{1})D_{1}^{ *} \bigl(t_{1},t' \bigr) \\ &{}+ v^{2}\omega_{0}^{2}\int _{0}^{t} dt_{1} \int _{0}^{t_{1}} dt_{2}\,G(t - t_{1})G(t_{1} - t_{2})\\ &{}\times e^{ - i\omega_{0}(t_{1} - t_{2})}D \bigl(t_{2},t' \bigr), \end{aligned}$$ where
$d(t,t') = \langle 0|\hat{Q}^{(0)}(t)\hat{Q}(t')|0 \rangle$ , and an analogous equation for d ∗(t′,t). We take into account only
$e^{i\omega_{0}(t_{1} - t_{2})}$ term of the factor 4cos(ω 0 t 1)cos(ω 0 t 2); other terms oscillate fast and drop out. Above the term ∝v may be omitted while it also oscillates fast. $$\begin{aligned}[c] &\int_{0}^{\infty} dt \int_{0}^{t} dt_{1} \int_{0}^{t_{1}} dt_{2} \,e^{i\omega t}\\ &\quad {} = \int_{0}^{\infty} dt_{2} \,e^{i\omega t_{2}} \int_{0}^{\infty} d \tau_{1}\,e^{i\omega \tau_{1}} \int_{0}^{\infty} d \tau \,e^{i\omega \tau} \end{aligned} $$ (t′→∞,τ=t−t 1,τ 1=t 1−t 2), one gets the following equation for D(ω) [3–5] (the factor e

$$D(\omega ) \simeq d(\omega ) + v^{2}G(\omega )G(\omega - 1)D(\omega ), $$ where

It is important to note that this spectrum is continuous although the excitation was monochromatic. This property of the emission under consideration was primarily predicted in [9–11] and it was recently experimentally verified in [22, 23].

Section1.Heading: Estimation of the number of generated photons
Section1.Para:
Let us present an estimation of the number of generated photons at the spontaneous down-conversion in a dielectric plate excited by strong quasi-monochromatic light pulse with the mean frequency ω 0 in visible. First we estimate the velocity (v) of the periodical change of the optical length in the plate under the laser excitation. To this end we consider the field generated by the laser pulse with the energy
$\mathcal {E} \approx 10^{ - 5}~\mathrm{J}$ and duration t=10−11 s focused to the area S 0=La, where L=0.01 m is the length and a=10−4 m is the width of the irradiated area. This corresponds to S 0=10−6 m2.The light intensity is
$I = \mathcal {E} / tS_{0} = 10^{12}~\mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2}$ . This intensity corresponds to the following strength of the electric field:
$$E = \sqrt{Z_{0}I} = 1.9 \cdot 10^{7}~\mathrm{V}/\mathrm{m} $$ (Z 0=376.73 Ohms is the free-space impedance). The velocity v can be estimated as follows: 19
$$ v = \chi^{(2)}EL / \lambda $$ We take χ (2)=10 pm/V and λ=10−6 m (1 μm). We get v=V/c 0≈1.9. The number of generated photon per excitation pulse for the pulse ω 0 t=105 equals
$$N = t\int_{0}^{\omega_{0}} \dot{N}(\omega )\,d\omega \approx \frac{\pi t\omega_{0}S}{160\lambda_{0}^{2}} \bigl( n_{0}^{2} - 1 \bigr) \frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}} \sim 10^{3} $$ i.e. around thousand photons per light pulse. For the repetition rate this means that ca one of every 1011 of photons of the frequency ω 0 will be converted to two photons with the frequencies ≈ω 0/2. Note that the total number of generated photons in case of v<c is determined by the total energy of the excitation pulse.

The efficiency may remarkably be enhanced if the excitation strength would correspond to the resonance condition v=2.94. In the case of the above considered laser with the energy
$\mathcal {E} \approx 10^{ - 5}~\mathrm{J}$ and duration t=10−11 s this condition will be fulfilled if one is to focus laser light to the area S=La with L=1 mm and a=0.34 mm. The efficiency of the process may be also remarkably enhanced using surface plasmon-polaritons for which the nonlinear susceptibility χ (2) may have much larger values than used here typical for usual dielectrics value of χ (2)=10 pm/V. Another possibility is given by the existence of the described above resonance: a careful choice of the of excitation condition together with the parameters of the dielectric or metal-dielectric interface would also allow one to essentially increase the efficiency of the spontaneous down-conversion.

Section1.Heading: Down-conversion in a SNOM tip
Section1.Para: Presented theory may be applied also for generation of polarization-entangled photon pairs in the metal-coated SNOM tip. Usually entangled photon pairs are generated by stimulated down-conversion in parametric oscillators. These oscillators generate photons in fixed directions and for fixed polarizations determined by the phase matching condition; the entanglement is only partial. Unlikely to that the entanglement of photons under consideration may be complete.

We consider the pump laser beam accessing the SNOM tip through the sufficiently short fiber (We consider the pump laser beam accessing the SNOM tip through the sufficiently short fiber (to avoid the suffering from cohesion caused by dispersion) along its symmetry axis z (see Fig. 3).
Fig. 3
The geometry of proposed experimental setup for generation of polarization-entangled photon pairs in the metal-coated SNOM tip

In the tip area the inversion symmetry along this axis is broken. In these conditions only three following non-zero components of the tensor χ (2) exist:
$\chi_{zzz}^{(2)}$ and
$\chi_{zxx}^{(2)} = \chi_{zyy}^{(2)}$ (here the first index corresponds to the electric field component of the pump photon, while the second and the third indices, respectively, to the electric field components of the signal and of the idler photons). One should interpret the action of these non-zero components in the following way. At the tip the incident pump wave has in addition to the transversal electric field also a longitudinal (z-polarized) field component. Therefore the non-zero values of the susceptibilities
$\chi_{z\alpha \alpha}^{(2)}$ (α=x,y,z) allow the generation (at the tip output) of entangled collinearly polarized photon pairs. Only the transverse (with respect to the z-direction) components of the wave vectors of photons are conserved here. Therefore, unlikely to parametric oscillator the emission under consideration occurs in a broad cone. In directions close to z the direction of polarization of the collinearly polarized photon pairs is arbitrary. This means that photon pairs emitted in this direction are characterized by complete polarization entanglement. Surface plasmons in the metal coating of the tip allow one to achieve the remarkable efficiency of the emission.

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: A theory of the nonparametric spontaneous down-conversion of monochromatic light in dielectric with non-zero value of the second-order nonlinear susceptibility is proposed. The photons in the process are generated by pairs and they are in the entangled states. The intensity of emission is determined by the amplitude of oscillations of the velocity of the optical length (eikonal) in time caused by the laser light. The spectrum of emission is continuous. In case of weak excitation the intensity of emission depends linearly on the laser intensity. At strong excitation the dependence of the process on the laser intensity changes drastically. It is found that a strong enhancement of the emission takes place near the critical intensity of excitation. The emission then is quasi-monochromatic; its frequency equals half of the frequency of the laser light. The further increasing of intensity will cause the weakening and the de-monochromatization of the emission. The crossover of the process occurs if the amplitude of oscillations of the optical length (eikonal) coincides with the wavelength of emission. Numerical consideration shows that the efficiency of the down-conversion under consideration for usual experimental conditions may be a few photons per trillion of exciting photons or more. The down-conversion in metal-coated SNOM tip may be used for generation of completely polarization-entangled photon pairs.
